Facility Location Problem

Posted on 2018-09-14 Edited on 2022-07-13

Problem

Suppose we have a set of facilities FFF and a set of clients CCC,
and would like to open a subset of facilities to serve the clients.
The cost consists of two parts:

  1. one for opening the selected facilities;
  2. one for connecting each client to its nearest facility.

Formally, denote fif_ifi​ the cost of facility i∈Fi \in Fi∈F and du,id_{u,i}du,i​ the distance from a client u∈Cu \in Cu∈C to a facility i∈Fi \in Fi∈F.
Further, we assume that the distances satisfy the following constraint:

dv,i≤dv,j+du,j+du,i,∀u,v∈C,i,j∈F. d_{v, i} \le d_{v, j} + d_{u, j} + d_{u, i}, \qquad \forall u, v \in C,\quad i, j \in F. dv,i​≤dv,j​+du,j​+du,i​,∀u,v∈C,i,j∈F.

Let S⊆FS \subseteq FS⊆F be a subset of facilities.
The cost of SSS is given by

∑i∈Sfi+∑u∈Cmin⁡i∈Sdu,i \sum_{i \in S} f_i + \sum_{u \in C} \min_{i \in S} d_{u,i} i∈S∑​fi​+u∈C∑​i∈Smin​du,i​

The problem is to find a set SSS that minimizes this cost.

Linear Programming

The linear program for the problem is given as follows:

min⁡∑i∈Ffiyi+∑u∈C,i∈Fdu,ixu,is.t.∑i∈Fxu,i≥1∀u∈C(1)yi−xu,i≥0∀i∈F,u∈C(2)xu,i≥0∀i∈F,u∈Cyi≥0∀i∈F \begin{array}{lrrlr} \min & \sum_{i \in F} f_i y_i + \sum_{u \in C, i \in F} d_{u, i} x_{u, i} & & \\ \text{s.t.} & \sum_{i \in F} x_{u, i} \ge 1 & \forall u \in C & (1) \\ & y_i - x_{u, i} \ge 0 & \forall i \in F, u \in C & (2) \\ & x_{u, i} \ge 0 & \forall i \in F, u \in C \\ & y_i \ge 0 & \forall i \in F \\ \end{array} mins.t.​∑i∈F​fi​yi​+∑u∈C,i∈F​du,i​xu,i​∑i∈F​xu,i​≥1yi​−xu,i​≥0xu,i​≥0yi​≥0​∀u∈C∀i∈F,u∈C∀i∈F,u∈C∀i∈F​(1)(2)​

The first constraint says that each client is assigned to at least one facility.
The second one says that a facility must be (fractionally) open if there is a client assigned to it.

Weak Duality   ⟹  \implies⟹ Dual Program

Let αu\alpha_uαu​ be the dual variable associated with constraint (1) and βu,i\beta_{u, i}βu,i​ be the one with constraint (2).
We want the following inequalities, called weak duality, to hold:

∑u∈Cαu=∑u∈Cαu⋅1+∑i∈F,u∈Cβu,i⋅0≤∑u∈Cαu⋅(∑i∈Fxu,i)+∑i∈F,u∈Cβu,i⋅(yi−xu,i)=∑i∈F,u∈C(αu−βu,i)⋅xu,i+∑i∈F((∑u∈Cβu,i)⋅yi)≤∑i∈F,u∈Cdu,ixu,i+∑i∈Ffiyi \begin{aligned} \sum_{u \in C} \alpha_u &= \sum_{u \in C} \alpha_u \cdot 1 + \sum_{i \in F, u \in C} \beta_{u, i} \cdot 0 \\ &\le \sum_{u \in C} \alpha_u \cdot \left( \sum_{i \in F} x_{u, i} \right) + \sum_{i \in F, u \in C} \beta_{u, i} \cdot (y_i - x_{u, i}) \\ &= \sum_{i \in F, u \in C} (\alpha_u - \beta_{u, i}) \cdot x_{u, i} + \sum_{i \in F} \left( \left( \sum_{u \in C} \beta_{u, i} \right) \cdot y_i \right) \\ &\le \sum_{i \in F, u \in C} d_{u, i} x_{u, i} + \sum_{i \in F} f_i y_i \end{aligned} u∈C∑​αu​​=u∈C∑​αu​⋅1+i∈F,u∈C∑​βu,i​⋅0≤u∈C∑​αu​⋅(i∈F∑​xu,i​)+i∈F,u∈C∑​βu,i​⋅(yi​−xu,i​)=i∈F,u∈C∑​(αu​−βu,i​)⋅xu,i​+i∈F∑​((u∈C∑​βu,i​)⋅yi​)≤i∈F,u∈C∑​du,i​xu,i​+i∈F∑​fi​yi​​

When such inequalities hold, ∑u∈Cαu\sum_{u \in C} \alpha_u∑u∈C​αu​ constitutes a lower bound for cost of the primal program.
The problem of obtaining a tightest such lower bound, under the constraints under which the above inequalities hold, gives the dual program:

max⁡∑u∈Cαus.t.αu−βu,i≤du,i∀i∈F,∀u∈C∑u∈Cβu,i≤fi∀i∈Fαu≥0,∀u∈Cβu,i≥0.∀u∈C,i∈F \begin{array}{rrrr} \max & \sum_{u \in C} \alpha_u \\ \text{s.t.}& \alpha_u - \beta_{u, i} \le d_{u,i} & \forall i \in F, \forall u \in C\\ & \sum_{u \in C} \beta_{u, i} \le f_i & \forall i \in F \\ & \alpha_u \ge 0, & \forall u \in C \\ & \beta_{u, i} \ge 0. & \forall u \in C, i \in F \end{array} maxs.t.​∑u∈C​αu​αu​−βu,i​≤du,i​∑u∈C​βu,i​≤fi​αu​≥0,βu,i​≥0.​∀i∈F,∀u∈C∀i∈F∀u∈C∀u∈C,i∈F​

Intuitive Explanation

Here we give a more intuitive way of deriving the dual.
First, observe that ∑u∈Cmin⁡i∈Fdu,i\sum_{u \in C} \min_{i \in F} d_{u,i}∑u∈C​mini∈F​du,i​ is a trivial lower bound of the primal programming.
In this case, each client is assigned to its nearest facility.
However we ignore facility cost entirely.

To incorporate the facility cost, for each facility iii we divide its cost fif_ifi​ among the clients, such that client uuu needs to pay βu,i\beta_{u, i}βu,i​ if it is assigned facility iii.
Note that βu,i\beta_{u, i}βu,i​ can be arbitrary non-negative number as long as it satisfies that ∑u∈Cβu,i=fi\sum_{u \in C} \beta_{u, i} = f_i∑u∈C​βu,i​=fi​ for all i∈Fi \in Fi∈F.

Theorem. For each subset S⊆FS \subseteq FS⊆F, let μ:C→S\mu : C \rightarrow Sμ:C→S be the function defined by

μS(u)≐arg⁡min⁡i∈S du,i . \mu_S (u) \doteq \underset{i \in S}{\arg \min}\, d_{u,i} \,. μS​(u)≐i∈Sargmin​du,i​.

We have

∑u∈C(du,μS(u)+βu,μS(u))≤∑i∈Sfi+∑u∈Cdu,μS(u) \begin{aligned} \sum_{u \in C} \left( d_{u, \mu_S (u)} + \beta_{u, \mu_S (u)} \right) \le \sum_{i \in S} f_i + \sum_{u \in C} d_{u, \mu_S (u)} \end{aligned} u∈C∑​(du,μS​(u)​+βu,μS​(u)​)≤i∈S∑​fi​+u∈C∑​du,μS​(u)​​

Proof. It suffices to show that

∑u∈Cβu,μS(u)≤∑i∈Sfi. \sum_{u \in C} \beta_{u, \mu_S (u)} \le \sum_{i \in S} f_i. u∈C∑​βu,μS​(u)​≤i∈S∑​fi​.

But this is obviously true, since

∑u∈Cβu,μS(u)≤∑u∈C(∑i∈Sβu,i)=∑i∈S(∑u∈Cβu,i)=∑i∈Sfi. \sum_{u \in C} \beta_{u, \mu_S (u)} \le \sum_{u \in C} \left( \sum_{i \in S} \beta_{u, i} \right) = \sum_{i \in S} \left( \sum_{u \in C} \beta_{u, i} \right) = \sum_{i \in S} f_i. u∈C∑​βu,μS​(u)​≤u∈C∑​(i∈S∑​βu,i​)=i∈S∑​(u∈C∑​βu,i​)=i∈S∑​fi​.

□\square□

If we define

αu=min⁡i∈F(du,i+βu,i), \alpha_u = \min_{i \in F} (d_{u,i} + \beta_{u, i}), αu​=i∈Fmin​(du,i​+βu,i​),

Then ∑u∈Cαu\sum_{u \in C} \alpha_u∑u∈C​αu​ constitutes a lower bound for the cost of each solution for the primal LP.
In particular, it is a lower bound of the cost of the optimal integral solution S∗S^*S∗ (its corresponding assignment function is denoted as μ∗\mu^*μ∗):

∑u∈Cαu≤∑i∈S∗fi+∑u∈S∗min⁡i∈Sdu,i. \begin{aligned} \sum_{u \in C} \alpha_u \le \sum_{i \in S^*} f_i + \sum_{u \in S^*} \min_{i \in S} d_{u,i}. \end{aligned} u∈C∑​αu​≤i∈S∗∑​fi​+u∈S∗∑​i∈Smin​du,i​.​

The problem of determining a set of βu,i\beta_{u, i}βu,i​'s that maximizes the lower bound ∑u∈Cαu\sum_{u \in C} \alpha_u∑u∈C​αu​ gives the dual program.

Complementary Slackness

min⁡∑i∈F,u∈Cdu,ixu,i+∑i∈Ffiyis.t.∑i∈Fxu,i≥1∀u∈Cyi−xu,i≥0∀i∈F,u∈Cxu,i≥0∀i∈F,u∈Cyi≥0∀i∈Fmax⁡∑u∈Cαus.t.αu−βu,i≤du,i∀i∈F,∀u∈C∑u∈Cβu,i≤fi∀i∈Fαu≥0,∀u∈Cβu,i≥0,∀u∈C,i∈F. \begin{array}{rrrr} \min & \sum_{i \in F, u \in C} d_{u, i} x_{u, i} + \sum_{i \in F} f_i y_i & & \\ \text{s.t.} & \sum_{i \in F} x_{u, i} \ge 1 & \forall u \in C \\ & y_i - x_{u, i} \ge 0 & \forall i \in F, u \in C \\ & x_{u, i} \ge 0 & \forall i \in F, u \in C \\ & y_i \ge 0 & \forall i \in F \\ \\ \max & \sum_{u \in C} \alpha_u \\ \text{s.t.}& \alpha_u - \beta_{u, i} \le d_{u,i} & \forall i \in F, \forall u \in C\\ & \sum_{u \in C} \beta_{u, i} \le f_i & \forall i \in F\\ & \alpha_u \ge 0, & \forall u \in C \\ & \beta_{u, i} \ge 0, & \forall u \in C, i \in F. \end{array} mins.t.maxs.t.​∑i∈F,u∈C​du,i​xu,i​+∑i∈F​fi​yi​∑i∈F​xu,i​≥1yi​−xu,i​≥0xu,i​≥0yi​≥0∑u∈C​αu​αu​−βu,i​≤du,i​∑u∈C​βu,i​≤fi​αu​≥0,βu,i​≥0,​∀u∈C∀i∈F,u∈C∀i∈F,u∈C∀i∈F∀i∈F,∀u∈C∀i∈F∀u∈C∀u∈C,i∈F.​

Let x∗,y∗x^*, y^*x∗,y∗ and α∗,β∗\alpha^*, \beta^*α∗,β∗ be the optimal primal and dual solutions, respectively.
For these set of variables, weak duality holds with equalities. By complementary slackness, it holds that

  1. αu∗=0\alpha^*_u = 0αu∗​=0 or ∑i∈Fxu,i∗=1\sum_{i \in F} x^*_{u, i} = 1∑i∈F​xu,i∗​=1
  2. βu,i∗=0\beta^*_{u, i} = 0βu,i∗​=0 or yi∗−xu,i∗=0y^*_i - x^*_{u, i} = 0yi∗​−xu,i∗​=0

and

  1. αu∗−βu,i∗=du,i\alpha^*_u - \beta^*_{u, i} = d_{u,i}αu∗​−βu,i∗​=du,i​ or xu,i∗=0x^*_{u, i} = 0xu,i∗​=0
  2. ∑u∈Cβu,i∗=fi\sum_{u \in C} \beta^*_{u, i} = f_i∑u∈C​βu,i∗​=fi​ or yi∗=0y^*_i = 0yi∗​=0

Deterministic Rounding [1]

444-Approximation Algorithm

We show how to pick a good subset S⊂FS \subset FS⊂F based on the optimal solutions x∗,y∗x^*, y^*x∗,y∗, α∗\alpha^*α∗ and β∗\beta^*β∗.

First we construct a graph G=(V,E)G = (V, E)G=(V,E) based on the x∗x^*x∗.

Definition. A derived graph from the optimal LP consists of the follows:

  1. The vertex set V=F∪CV = F \cup CV=F∪C;
  2. The undirected edge set E={(u,i):xu,i∗>0,∀i∈F,u∈C}E = \{ (u, i) : x^*_{u, i} > 0, \forall i \in F, u \in C\}E={(u,i):xu,i∗​>0,∀i∈F,u∈C}, i.e., the edge set EEE consists of client-facility pairs (u,i)(u, i)(u,i) for which xu,i∗>0x^*_{u, i} > 0xu,i∗​>0.

In the graph GGG, the neighbors a client u∈Cu \in Cu∈C can only be facilities.

Definition. For each u∈Cu \in Cu∈C, let N(u)N(u)N(u) be the set of facilities adjacent to uuu in GGG.

Similarly, we define two-hop neighbors of a client CCC, as the client who connects to uuu via a intermediate facility.

Definition. For a client u∈Cu \in Cu∈C, its two hop neighbors are the set of clients vvv whose distance to uuu is at most 222:

N2(u)={v∈C:N(u)∩N(v)≠∅}. N^2(u) = \{ v \in C: N(u) \cap N(v) \neq \emptyset \}. N2(u)={v∈C:N(u)∩N(v)=∅}.

Note that u∈N2(u)u \in N^2(u)u∈N2(u).

Below is an example. The cycles represent clients and the squares are for facilities. Associated each client and each facility are the αu∗\alpha_u^*αu∗​ value and opening cost respectively.

An important property of this graph is that

Property. If (u,i)∈E(u, i) \in E(u,i)∈E, then xu,i∗>0x^*_{u, i} >0xu,i∗​>0, which implies that αu∗=du,i+βu,i∗\alpha^*_u =d_{u,i} + \beta^*_{u, i}αu∗​=du,i​+βu,i∗​ by complementary slackness.
It concludes that αu∗≥du,i\alpha^*_u \ge d_{u,i}αu∗​≥du,i​ if there is an edge (u,i)(u, i)(u,i) in GGG.

The following is the first constant factor approximation algorithm for the un-capacitated facility location problem, proposed in 1997 [1].

Algorithm 1

  1. S←∅S \leftarrow \emptysetS←∅
  2. U←C; B←∅U \leftarrow C;\, B \leftarrow \emptysetU←C;B←∅
  3. while U≠∅U \neq \emptysetU=∅ do
  4. \quad u←arg⁡min⁡ v∈U αv∗u \leftarrow \underset{v \in U}{\arg \min \,} \,\alpha^*_vu←v∈Uargmin​αv∗​
  5. \quad iu←arg⁡min⁡ i∈N(u) fii_u \leftarrow \underset{i \in N(u)}{\arg \min \,} \,f_iiu​←i∈N(u)argmin​fi​
  6. \quad U←U∖N2(u)U \leftarrow U \setminus N^2(u)U←U∖N2(u)
  7. \quad B←B∪{u}B \leftarrow B \cup \{ u \}B←B∪{u}
  8. \quad S←S∪{iu}S \leftarrow S \cup \{ i_u \}S←S∪{iu​}

It is important that at each iteration, when a client uuu is chosen, all vertices clients in N2(u)N^2(u)N2(u) are removed from UUU.
This guarantees that clients in BBB has non-overlapping neighbors, i.e.,

N(u)∩N(v)=∅, ∀u,v∈B. N(u) \cap N(v) = \emptyset,\, \quad \forall u, v \in B. N(u)∩N(v)=∅,∀u,v∈B.

Consider the assignment scheme in which, instead of assigning each client to its nearest facility in SSS, at each iteration, we assign clients in N2(u)N^2(u)N2(u) to the chosen facility iui_uiu​.
Then each iteration of the algorithm creates a clusters, which contains three kinds of vertices:

  1. The selected client uuu with minimum αu∗\alpha^*_uαu∗​.
  2. All uuu’s neighboring facilities.
  3. All un-assigned clients neighboring to these facilities.

Such clusters are non-overlapping.

The example above shows one iteration of the algorithm.
The vertex with minimum value of αu∗\alpha^*_uαu∗​ (i.e. 1) is opened, highlighted by the red cycle.
There are two facilities connected to it, the cheap opening cost of which is 111.
Then all un-assigned clients neighboring these two facilities are assigned to the cost 1 facility, as shown by the purple dashed arrows.

It is left to analyze the cost of the solution returned.

Theorem. The facility cost of Algorithm 111 is at most OPT.

Proof.

At each iteration, a client uuu is selected. In the primal LP, constraint (1) requires that

∑i∈Fxu,i∗≥1 \sum_{i \in F} x^*_{u, i} \ge 1 i∈F∑​xu,i∗​≥1

Note that although uuu can assigned to a facility fractionally, the total amount of assignment must be at least 111.
Further, although a facility can be fractionally open in primal LP, the constraint (2)

yi∗≥xu,i∗ y^*_i \ge x^*_{u, i} yi∗​≥xu,i∗​

implies that the open amount must be at least the amount a client assign to it.
We conclude that

min⁡i∈N(u)fi≤(min⁡i∈N(u)fi)⋅∑i∈N(u)xu,i∗≤∑i∈N(u)xu,i∗⋅fi≤∑i∈N(u)yi∗⋅fi. \begin{array}{llr} \min_{i \in N(u)} f_i &\le \big( \min_{i \in N(u)} f_i \big) \cdot \sum_{i \in N(u)} x^*_{u, i} \\ &\le \sum_{i \in N(u)} x^*_{u, i} \cdot f_i \\ &\le \sum_{i \in N(u)} y^*_{i} \cdot f_{i}. \end{array} mini∈N(u)​fi​​≤(mini∈N(u)​fi​)⋅∑i∈N(u)​xu,i∗​≤∑i∈N(u)​xu,i∗​⋅fi​≤∑i∈N(u)​yi∗​⋅fi​.​

The neighbor sets N(u)N(u)N(u)'s of the selected clients u∈Bu \in Bu∈B are disjoint.

Therefore, summing over u∈Bu \in Bu∈B, the total facility cost is bounded by

∑u∈B∑i∈N(u)yi∗fi≤∑i∈Fyi∗fi≤OPT. \sum_{u \in B} \sum_{i \in N(u)} y^*_{i} f_{i} \le \sum_{i \in F} y^*_i f_i \le OPT. u∈B∑​i∈N(u)∑​yi∗​fi​≤i∈F∑​yi∗​fi​≤OPT.

Theorem. The connection cost of Algorithm 111 is at most 3⋅3 \cdot3⋅OPT.

Proof.
Now we analyze the assignment cost.

Case One. If u∈Bu \in Bu∈B, then it is selected by the algorithm, and iu≐arg⁡min⁡i∈N(u)fii_u \doteq \arg \min_{i \in N(u)} f_iiu​≐argmini∈N(u)​fi​ belongs to SSS.
Therefore,

du,S≐arg⁡min⁡i∈Sdu,i≤di,iu≤αu∗. d_{u, S} \doteq \arg \min_{i \in S} d_{u, i} \le d_{i, i_u} \le \alpha_u^*. du,S​≐argi∈Smin​du,i​≤di,iu​​≤αu∗​.

Case Two. If v∉Bv \notin Bv∈/B, then v∈N2(u)v \in N^2(u)v∈N2(u) for some u∈Bu \in Bu∈B.
Since v∈N2(u)v \in N^2(u)v∈N2(u), there exists some facility j∈N(v)∩N(u)j \in N(v) \cap N(u)j∈N(v)∩N(u).
By triangle inequality, we have

dv,iu≤dv,j+du,j+dv,iu≤αv∗+αu∗+αu∗≤3αv∗ d_{v , i_u} \le d_{v, j} + d_{u, j} + d_{v, i_u} \le \alpha^*_v + \alpha^*_u + \alpha^*_u \le 3 \alpha^*_v dv,iu​​≤dv,j​+du,j​+dv,iu​​≤αv∗​+αu∗​+αu∗​≤3αv∗​

The last inequality holds since αu∗≤αv∗\alpha^*_u \le \alpha^*_vαu∗​≤αv∗​.

□\square□

Combing assignment cost and facility cost, Algorithm 111 is 444-approximation.

How happy are we with the 444-approximation algorithm? Probably not. In the previous example, when a facility is opened, only one client contributes to its opening cost.
However, in the primal solution, many other clients assigned to it do not contribute to the opening cost, which implies that the current analysis may not be tight.

Randomized Rounding [3]

333-Approximation Rounding

In the section, we improve the approximation ratio of 444 to an expected value of 333.
In the previous rounding, we bound the opening cost as

∑u∈Bmin⁡i∈N(u)fi≤OPT \sum_{u \in B} \min_{i \in N(u) } f_i \le OPT u∈B∑​i∈N(u)min​fi​≤OPT

which is not tight.

Define the assignment cost for client uuu in the optimal primal LP solution as Au=∑i∈Fxu,i∗du,iA_u = \sum_{i \in F} x^*_{u, i} d_{u,i}Au​=∑i∈F​xu,i∗​du,i​.
Indeed, it is affordable to bound

∑u∈B∑i∈N(u)xu,i∗fi+∑u∈BAu≤OPT \sum_{u \in B} \sum_{i \in N(u) } x^*_{u, i} f_i + \sum_{u \in B} A_u \le OPT u∈B∑​i∈N(u)∑​xu,i∗​fi​+u∈B∑​Au​≤OPT

It is possible to devise a randomized rounding algorithm that incorporates this cost and improve the approximation ratio to 333.
The only differences compared to the first rounding algorithm are

  1. We pick a client that minimize αu∗+Au\alpha^*_u + A_uαu∗​+Au​;
  2. We pick a facility with probability xu,i∗x^*_{u, i}xu,i∗​.

Below is the algorithm.

Algorithm 2

  1. S←∅S \leftarrow \emptysetS←∅
  2. U←C; B←∅U \leftarrow C;\, B \leftarrow \emptysetU←C;B←∅
  3. while U≠∅U \neq \emptysetU=∅ do
  4. \quad u←arg⁡min⁡ v∈U (αv∗+Av)u \leftarrow \underset{v \in U}{\arg \min \,} \,\big( \alpha^*_v + A_v \big)u←v∈Uargmin​(αv∗​+Av​)
  5. \quad Pr⁡[iu←i]=xu,i∗,∀i∈N(u)\Pr[ i_u \leftarrow i ] = x^*_{u, i}, \quad \forall i \in N(u)Pr[iu​←i]=xu,i∗​,∀i∈N(u)
  6. \quad U←U∖N2(u)U \leftarrow U \setminus N^2(u)U←U∖N2(u)
  7. \quad B←B∪{u}B \leftarrow B \cup \{ u \}B←B∪{u}
  8. \quad S←S∪{iu}S \leftarrow S \cup \{ i_u \}S←S∪{iu​}

Facility Cost

The analysis of expected facility cost is almost the same as before. It is guaranteed that

N(u)∩N(v)=∅,∀u,v∈N(u). N(u) \cap N(v) = \emptyset, \qquad \forall u, v \in N(u). N(u)∩N(v)=∅,∀u,v∈N(u).

Therefore, the expected opening cost is bounded by

∑u∈B∑i∈N(u)xu,i∗⋅fi≤∑u∈B∑i∈N(u)yi∗⋅fi≤∑i∈Fyi∗fi. \sum_{u \in B} \sum_{i \in N(u) } x^*_{u, i} \cdot f_i \le \sum_{u \in B} \sum_{i \in N(u) } y^*_i \cdot f_i \le \sum_{i \in F} y_i^* f_i. u∈B∑​i∈N(u)∑​xu,i∗​⋅fi​≤u∈B∑​i∈N(u)∑​yi∗​⋅fi​≤i∈F∑​yi∗​fi​.

Connection Cost

Now we analyze the assignment cost.

Case One. If u∈Bu \in Bu∈B, then

E[min⁡i∈Sdu,i]≤E[du,iu]=∑i∈N(u)xu,i∗⋅du,i. \mathbb{E}[ \min_{i \in S} d_{u, i} ] \le \mathbb{E}[ d_{u, i_u} ] = \sum_{i \in N(u)} x^*_{u, i} \cdot d_{u, i}. E[i∈Smin​du,i​]≤E[du,iu​​]=i∈N(u)∑​xu,i∗​⋅du,i​.

Case One. If v∉Bv \notin Bv∈/B, then there exists u∈Bu \in Bu∈B, s.t., v∈N2(u)v \in N^2(u)v∈N2(u).
Then there exists some facility j∈N(u)∩N(v)j \in N(u) \cap N(v)j∈N(u)∩N(v).
By triangle inequality, the expected connection cost is at most

E[min⁡i∈Sdv,i]≤E[dv,iu]≤E[du,iu+du,j+dv,j]=∑i∈N(u)xu,i∗⋅du,i+du,j+dv,j≤Au+αu∗+αv∗≤Au+2αv∗. \begin{aligned} \mathbb{E}[ \min_{i \in S} d_{v, i} ] &\le \mathbb{E}[ d_{v, i_u} ] \le \mathbb{E}[ d_{u, i_u} + d_{u, j} + d_{v, j} ] \\ &= \sum_{i \in N(u)} x^*_{u, i} \cdot d_{u, i} + d_{u, j} + d_{v, j} \\ &\le A_u + \alpha^*_{u} + \alpha^*_v \le A_u + 2 \alpha^*_v. \end{aligned} E[i∈Smin​dv,i​]​≤E[dv,iu​​]≤E[du,iu​​+du,j​+dv,j​]=i∈N(u)∑​xu,i∗​⋅du,i​+du,j​+dv,j​≤Au​+αu∗​+αv∗​≤Au​+2αv∗​.​

Total Cost

The cost is at most

∑i∈Fyi∗fi+∑i∈F,u∈Cdu,i⋅xu,i∗+2∑u∈Cαu∗≤3⋅OPT \sum_{i \in F} y_i^* f_i + \sum_{i \in F, u \in C} d_{u, i} \cdot x^*_{u, i} + 2\sum_{u \in C} \alpha^*_u \le 3 \cdot OPT i∈F∑​yi∗​fi​+i∈F,u∈C∑​du,i​⋅xu,i∗​+2u∈C∑​αu∗​≤3⋅OPT

Remark: there is still room for improvement.
When a client uuu is selected and a facility iii is sampled, v∈N2(u)v \in N^2(u)v∈N2(u) is assigned to iii.
On the other hand, vvv itself may contributes to the opening cost of some other facility not open.
To make the expected opening cost tight, we may consider opening facilities directly with respect to probability yi∗y^*_iyi∗​.

(1+3/e)(1 + 3/e)(1+3/e)-Approximation Rounding [3]

In the previous analysis, we see that a facility may be under-sampled.
There are two reasons for this:

  1. For a facility iii, ∃u∈N(i)\exists u \in N(i)∃u∈N(i) such that u∈Bu \in Bu∈B. When uuu is selected, facility iii is sampled with probability xu,i∗x^*_{u, i}xu,i∗​, which might be smaller than yi∗y^*_iyi∗​.

  2. For a facility iii, none of its clients u∈N(i)u \in N(i)u∈N(i) is selected, therefore iii is never sampled.

To fix theses issues and based on Algorithm 222, we have the following algorithm.
The algorithm presented here is a modified version of the one proposed in [3], but guided the same philosophy.

Algorithm 3:

  1. T←FT \leftarrow FT←F
  2. k←0k \leftarrow 0k←0
  3. S1,S2,S3←∅S_1, S_2, S_3 \leftarrow \emptysetS1​,S2​,S3​←∅
  4. while there exists un-assigned client do
  5. \quad k←k+1k \leftarrow k + 1k←k+1
  6. \quad Let uku_kuk​ be the unassigned one with smallest αu∗\alpha^*_uαu∗​
  7. \quad Open exactly one facility ik∈N(uk)i_k \in N( u_k )ik​∈N(uk​) with probability xu,i∗x^*_{u, i}xu,i∗​
  8. \quad S1←S1∪{ik}S_1 \leftarrow S_1 \cup \{ i_k \}S1​←S1​∪{ik​}
  9. \quad For each i∈N(uk)−{ik}i \in N(u_k) - \{ i_k \}i∈N(uk​)−{ik​}
  10. \qquad Open iii with probability (yi∗−xu,i∗)/(1−xu,i∗)(y^*_{i} - x^*_{u, i} ) / ( 1- x^*_{u, i} )(yi∗​−xu,i∗​)/(1−xu,i∗​)
  11. \qquad \quad S2←S2∪{i}S_2 \leftarrow S_2 \cup \{ i \}S2​←S2​∪{i}
  12. \quad T←T−N(uk)T \leftarrow T - N(u_k)T←T−N(uk​)
  13. \quad Assign vvv to iki_kik​, for each v∈N2(uk)v \in N^2( u_k )v∈N2(uk​)
  14. for each facility i∈Ti \in Ti∈T
  15. \quad Open iii with probability yi∗y^*_iyi∗​
  16. \qquad S3←S3∪{i}S_3 \leftarrow S_3 \cup \{ i \}S3​←S3​∪{i}
  17. Re-assign each u∈Cu \in Cu∈C to its nearest open facility.

When the algorithm stops, denote S=S1∪S2∪S3S = S_1 \cup S_2 \cup S_3S=S1​∪S2​∪S3​ the set of open facilities and B={u1,u2,...,u∣B∣}B = \{u_1, u_2, ..., u_{|B| } \}B={u1​,u2​,...,u∣B∣​} the set of selected clients by line 666.
The following lemma shows that Algorithm 333 fully samples each facility and therefore never loses to Algorithm 111.

Facility Cost

Lemma 1. For each i∈Fi \in Fi∈F, it is opened with probability yi∗y^*_iyi∗​.

Proof. Note the facilities are not open independently. The claim is trivially true if a facility is is sampled in line 10. Otherwise, ∃u∈B\exists u \in B∃u∈B, s.t., i∈N(u)i \in N(u)i∈N(u). The probability of iii being open is

xu,i∗+(1−xu,i∗)⋅yi∗−xu,i∗1−xu,i∗=yi∗. x^*_{u, i} + ( 1 - x^*_{u, i} ) \cdot \frac{y^*_{i} - x^*_{u, i} }{ 1- x^*_{u, i} } = y^*_i. xu,i∗​+(1−xu,i∗​)⋅1−xu,i∗​yi∗​−xu,i∗​​=yi∗​.

■\blacksquare■

Corollary. By linearity of expectation, the expected facility opening cost is ∑i∈Fyi∗fi\sum_{i \in F} y^*_i f_i∑i∈F​yi∗​fi​.

Connection Cost

What is not trivial is the analysis of the assignment cost.
Given SSS, assigning u∈Cu \in Cu∈C to its nearest facility in SSS minimizes the assignment cost.
To bound this cost, we investigate a sub-optimal assignment based on SSS.
For each u∈Cu \in Cu∈C we select a subset S(u)⊆SS(u) \subseteq SS(u)⊆S and assign it to a closest facility in S(u)S(u)S(u).
This leads to a possibly increase in the expected assignment cost.

Let ZZZ be the random variable of the assignment cost for client uuu and XiX_iXi​ (i∈N(u)i \in N(u)i∈N(u)) be the indicator random variable of iii being in S(u)S(u)S(u).
As when none of the facility in N(u)N(u)N(u) is selected into S(u)S(u)S(u), then assignment cost is bounded by 3⋅αu∗3 \cdot \alpha^*_u3⋅αu∗​, the value of ZZZ is therefore at most

Z≤min⁡i∈N(u),Xi=1{du,i⋅Xi}+3αu∗⋅I[Xi=0,∀i∈N(u)] Z \le \min_{i \in N(u), X_i = 1} \{ d_{u, i} \cdot X_i \} + 3 \alpha^*_u \cdot \mathbb{I}_{[ X_i = 0, \forall i \in N(u)] } Z≤i∈N(u),Xi​=1min​{du,i​⋅Xi​}+3αu∗​⋅I[Xi​=0,∀i∈N(u)]​

The goal is to provide a method for generating S(u)S(u)S(u), such that

  1. Pr⁡[Xi=1]=xu,i∗\Pr[X_i = 1] = x^*_{u, i}Pr[Xi​=1]=xu,i∗​, for ∀i∈N(u)\forall i \in N(u)∀i∈N(u);
  2. Pr⁡[I[Xi=0,∀i∈N(u)]=1]≤1/e\Pr[\mathbb{I}_{[ X_i = 0, \forall i \in N(u)]} = 1 ] \le 1/ePr[I[Xi​=0,∀i∈N(u)]​=1]≤1/e.

Any such generation method satisfies to bound the assignment cost of client uuu:

E[Z]≤E[∑i∈N(u)du,iXi+3αu∗⋅I[Xi=0,∀i∈N(u)]]=∑i∈N(u)du,iE[Xi]+3αu∗⋅E[I[Xi=0,∀i∈N(u)]]≤∑i∈N(u)du,ixu,i∗+3eαu∗ \begin{aligned} \mathbb{E}[Z] &\le \mathbb{E} \left[ \sum_{i \in N(u)} d_{u, i} X_i + 3 \alpha^*_u \cdot \mathbb{I}_{[ X_i = 0, \forall i \in N(u)] } \right] \\ &= \sum_{i \in N(u)} d_{u, i} \mathbb{E}[X_i] + 3 \alpha^*_u \cdot \mathbb{E}\left[ \mathbb{I}_{[ X_i = 0, \forall i \in N(u)] } \right] \\ &\le \sum_{i \in N(u) } d_{u, i} x^*_{u, i} + \frac{3}{e} \alpha^*_u \end{aligned} E[Z]​≤E⎣⎢⎡​i∈N(u)∑​du,i​Xi​+3αu∗​⋅I[Xi​=0,∀i∈N(u)]​⎦⎥⎤​=i∈N(u)∑​du,i​E[Xi​]+3αu∗​⋅E[I[Xi​=0,∀i∈N(u)]​]≤i∈N(u)∑​du,i​xu,i∗​+e3​αu∗​​

Note that the inequality here may not be tight, as we replace the min⁡\minmin operation into ∑\sum∑.
But it suffices to prove the expected approximation ratio.
When combined with the expected facility opening cost, we know that total expected cost is bounded by

∑i∈Fyi∗fi+∑u∈C∑i∈N(u)du,ixu,i∗+3eαu∗=(1+3e)⋅OPT \sum_{i \in F} y^*_i f_i + \sum_{u \in C} \sum_{i \in N(u) } d_{u, i} x^*_{u, i} + \frac{3}{e} \alpha^*_u = \left( 1 + \frac{3}{e} \right) \cdot OPT i∈F∑​yi∗​fi​+u∈C∑​i∈N(u)∑​du,i​xu,i∗​+e3​αu∗​=(1+e3​)⋅OPT

The S(u)S(u)S(u) is generated as follows.
If u∈Bu \in Bu∈B, then we let S(u)=SS(u) = SS(u)=S.
Otherwise, we initialize S(u)S(u)S(u) with S−N(u)S - N(u)S−N(u), and for facility i∈N(u)∩Si \in N(u) \cap Si∈N(u)∩S, we perform some carefully designed operations to ensure that Pr⁡[i∈S(u)]=xu,i∗\Pr[i \in S(u) ]= x^*_{u, i}Pr[i∈S(u)]=xu,i∗​.

  1. If i∈S3i \in S_3i∈S3​, we keep it in S(u)S(u)S(u) with probability xu,i∗yi∗\frac{x^*_{u, i} } {y^*_i}yi∗​xu,i∗​​. Therefore,

    Pr⁡[i∈S(u)]=Pr⁡[i∈S(u)∣i∈S]⋅Pr⁡[i∈S]=xu,i∗ \Pr[i \in S(u)] = \Pr[i \in S(u) \mid i \in S] \cdot \Pr[i \in S] = x^*_{u, i} Pr[i∈S(u)]=Pr[i∈S(u)∣i∈S]⋅Pr[i∈S]=xu,i∗​

  2. Otherwise, ∃uk∈B\exists u_k \in B∃uk​∈B, such that i∈N(uk)i \in N(u_k)i∈N(uk​). There are two possible cases

    1. Case 1: xi,uk∗≥xu,i∗x^*_{i,u_k} \ge x^*_{u, i}xi,uk​∗​≥xu,i∗​, the probability of selecting iii is defined as follows:

      Pr⁡[i∈S(u)∣i∈S]={xu,i∗/xi,uk∗,i∈S10,i∈S2 \Pr[i \in S(u) \mid i \in S] = \begin{cases} \begin{array}{lr} {x^*_{u, i} } / { x^*_{i,u_k} }, &i \in S_1 \\ 0, & i \in S_2 \end{array} \end{cases} Pr[i∈S(u)∣i∈S]={xu,i∗​/xi,uk​∗​,0,​i∈S1​i∈S2​​​

      Therefore,

    2. Case 2: xi,uk∗<xu,i∗x^*_{i,u_k} < x^*_{u, i}xi,uk​∗​<xu,i∗​, the probability of selecting iii is defined as follows:

      Pr⁡[i∈S(u)∣i∈S]={1,i∈S1(xu,i∗−xi,uk∗)⋅(1−xi,uk∗)/(yi∗−xi,uk∗),i∈S2 \Pr[i \in S(u) \mid i \in S] = \begin{cases} \begin{array}{lr} 1, &i \in S_1 \\ (x^*_{u, i} - x^*_{i, u_k} ) \cdot ( 1 - x^*_{i,u_k } ) / (y^*_{i} - x^*_{i,u_k } ), & i \in S_2 \end{array} \end{cases} Pr[i∈S(u)∣i∈S]={1,(xu,i∗​−xi,uk​∗​)⋅(1−xi,uk​∗​)/(yi∗​−xi,uk​∗​),​i∈S1​i∈S2​​​

      The probability is well defined as yi∗≥xu,i∗y^*_i \ge x^*_{u, i}yi∗​≥xu,i∗​. It follows

      Pr⁡[i∈S(u)]=Pr⁡[i∈S(u)∣i∈S1]⋅Pr⁡[i∈S1]+Pr⁡[i∈S(u)∣i∈S2]⋅Pr⁡[i∈S2]=xi,uk∗+(xu,i∗−xi,uk∗)⋅(1−xi,uk∗)/(yi∗−xi,uk∗)⋅(yi∗−xi,uk∗)/(xu,i∗−xi,uk∗)=xu,i∗\begin{array}{ll} \Pr[i \in S(u)] &= \Pr[i \in S(u) |i \in S_1 ] \cdot \Pr[ i \in S_1 ] + \Pr[i \in S(u) |i \in S_2 ] \cdot \Pr[ i \in S_2 ] \\ &= x^*_{i,u_k} + (x^*_{u, i} - x^*_{i, u_k} ) \cdot ( 1 - x^*_{i,u_k } ) / (y^*_{i} - x^*_{i,u_k } ) \cdot (y^*_{i} - x^*_{i,u_k } ) / (x^*_{u, i} - x^*_{i, u_k} )\\ &= x^*_{u, i} \end{array} Pr[i∈S(u)]​=Pr[i∈S(u)∣i∈S1​]⋅Pr[i∈S1​]+Pr[i∈S(u)∣i∈S2​]⋅Pr[i∈S2​]=xi,uk​∗​+(xu,i∗​−xi,uk​∗​)⋅(1−xi,uk​∗​)/(yi∗​−xi,uk​∗​)⋅(yi∗​−xi,uk​∗​)/(xu,i∗​−xi,uk​∗​)=xu,i∗​​

It is left to show that Pr⁡[I[Xi=0,∀i∈N(u)]=1]≤1/e\Pr[\mathbb{I}_{[ X_i = 0, \forall i \in N(u)]} = 1 ] \le 1/ePr[I[Xi​=0,∀i∈N(u)]​=1]≤1/e.
For u∈Bu \in Bu∈B, this holds trivially.
If not, we prove the following lemma.

Lemma 2. For any client u∈C∖Bu \in C \setminus Bu∈C∖B, the probability that none of facility in N(u)N(u)N(u) belongs to S(u)S(u)S(u) is bounded by 1/e1/ e1/e.

constitutes a partition of FFF.

Primal-Dual Algorithm [2]

In this section we show a primal-dual algorithm that is purely combinatorial.

  1. Initially we have a set of dual variables αu,u∈C\alpha_u, u \in Cαu​,u∈C and βu,i,u∈C,i∈F\beta_{u,i}, u \in C, i \in Fβu,i​,u∈C,i∈F that are set to 000.
    Note that they are feasible.

  2. Then we try to optimize this set of variables by increasing all αu,u∈C\alpha_u, u \in Cαu​,u∈C in parallel until some αu\alpha_uαu​’s are blocked.

Why are they blocked? Because the dual constraint

αu≤du,i+βu,i \alpha_u \le d_{u,i} + \beta_{u,i} αu​≤du,i​+βu,i​

becomes tight for some client u∈Cu \in Cu∈C.
If we increase αu\alpha_uαu​ further, the variables are no longer dual feasible.
However, we can modify our strategy by increasing these βu,i\beta_{u,i}βu,i​ simultaneously with αu\alpha_uαu​ until facility iii is blocked, i.e.,

∑u∈Cβu,i=fi. \sum_{u \in C} \beta_{u,i} = f_i. u∈C∑​βu,i​=fi​.

Definition. For each facility i∈Fi \in Fi∈F, define its neighbors N(i)N(i)N(i) as to be the clients such that αu≥du,i\alpha_u \ge d_{u,i}αu​≥du,i​.

The algorithm for constructing the dual variables are given as follows.

Algorithm. Increasing the Dual

  1. U←CU \leftarrow CU←C: the set of un-blocked clients.
  2. B←∅B \leftarrow \emptysetB←∅: the set of blocked facilities.
  3. while U≠∅U \neq \emptysetU=∅ do
  4. \quad For ∀u∈U\forall u \in U∀u∈U
  5. \qquad Increase all αu\alpha_uαu​ (if necessary, βu,i\beta_{u,i}βu,i​ for some iii ) simultaneously
  6. \quad Until either
  7. \qquad some facility i∉Bi \notin Bi∈/B is blocked:
  8. \qquad\quad B←B∪{i}B \leftarrow B \cup \{i \}B←B∪{i}
  9. \qquad\quad U←U∖N(i)U \leftarrow U \setminus N(i)U←U∖N(i)
  10. \qquad some client uuu neighbors a blocked facility i∈Bi \in Bi∈B:
  11. \qquad\quad U←U∖{u}U \leftarrow U \setminus \{ u \}U←U∖{u}

Question to Ponder. What is the running time for the Dual Variable Increment algorithm.

After running the algorithm above, we get a set of maximal variables which we can’t simultaneously increase any more.
It has the following property

Property. Each client u∈Cu \in Cu∈C neighbors at least one block facility.

If not, the algorithm will not stop since UUU is not empty.

Next, we show how to construct an approximate solution from the maximal dual variables.
First we construct a graph G=(V,E)G = (V, E)G=(V,E) based on the dual LP.

  1. The vertex set V=B∪CV = B \cup CV=B∪C.
  2. The edge set E={(u,i):αu≥du,i,u∈C,∀i∈B}E = \{ (u, i) : \alpha_u \ge d_{u,i}, u \in C, \forall i \in B \}E={(u,i):αu​≥du,i​,u∈C,∀i∈B}.

Moreover, if βu,i>0\beta_{u,i} > 0βu,i​>0 for some i∈Fi \in Fi∈F, u∈Cu \in Cu∈C, we say that uuu contributes to iii.

Definition. For each facility i∈Fi \in Fi∈F, let N+(i)N^+(i)N+(i) be set of clients contributing to it.

Algorithm. Facility Selection

  1. S←∅S \leftarrow \emptysetS←∅.
  2. while B≠∅B \neq \emptysetB=∅ do
  3. \quad Let i∈Bi \in Bi∈B be the earliest blocked facility.
  4. \quad S←S∪{i}S \leftarrow S \cup \{ i \}S←S∪{i}
  5. \quad // Remove all facilities i′i'i′ if ∃u∈C\exists u \in C∃u∈C that contributes to both iii and i′i'i′.
  6. \quad B←B∖{i′∈B:N+(i)∩N+(i′)≠∅}B \leftarrow B \setminus \{ i' \in B : N^+(i) \cap N^+(i') \neq \emptyset \}B←B∖{i′∈B:N+(i)∩N+(i′)=∅}.

The figure below shows an example of dual variable increment algorithm.

The figure below shows the corresponding derived graph.

The figure below shows an example of facility selection. The selected facilities are marked with dark green. The clients contributing to theses facilities are connected to them red lines.

Facility Cost

We can show by induction that when a blocked facility is selected, its opening cost is fully covered by all clients contributing to this facility.
Note that if any other blocked facility is connected to any of these clients, it is removed from the candidate set.
Therefore, when a new blocked facility iii is selected, the clients in N+(i)N^+(i)N+(i) can not contribute to any previous selected facility.

The cost of open facilities in SSS, plus the cost of connecting clients in N+(i)N^+(i)N+(i) for i∈Si \in Si∈S, is given by

∑i∈S(fi+∑u∈N+(i)du,i)=∑i∈S(∑u∈N+(i)βi,j+∑u∈N+(i)du,i)=∑i∈S∑u∈N+(i)αu \sum_{i \in S} \left( f_i + \sum_{u \in N^+(i)} d_{u,i} \right) = \sum_{i \in S} \left( \sum_{u \in N^+(i)} \beta_{i,j} + \sum_{u \in N^+(i)} d_{u,i} \right) = \sum_{i \in S} \sum_{u \in N^+(i)} \alpha_u i∈S∑​⎝⎛​fi​+u∈N+(i)∑​du,i​⎠⎞​=i∈S∑​⎝⎛​u∈N+(i)∑​βi,j​+u∈N+(i)∑​du,i​⎠⎞​=i∈S∑​u∈N+(i)∑​αu​

Connection Cost

It is left to consider a client uuu not in N+(i)N^+(i)N+(i) for any i∈Si \in Si∈S.

Case One. u∈N(i)u \in N(i)u∈N(i) for some i∈Si \in Si∈S, then the connection cost is

du,i=αu d_{u,i} = \alpha_u du,i​=αu​

Case Two.
Otherwise, by the property of the algorithm, we know that there exists a facility iii that stops αu\alpha_uαu​ from increasing.
The reason that iii is not selected is that when some other facility i′i'i′ is selected into SSS, iii is removed from the candidate set BBB because N+(i)∩N+(i′)≠∅N^+(i) \cap N^+(i') \neq \emptysetN+(i)∩N+(i′)=∅.

Lemma. Let v∈N+(i)∩N+(i′)v \in N^+(i) \cap N^+(i')v∈N+(i)∩N+(i′). Then αv≤αu\alpha_{v} \le \alpha_uαv​≤αu​

Proof.

When iii stops αu\alpha_uαu​, since vvv also contributes to iii,

  1. either αv\alpha_{v}αv​ has stopped from increasing or
  2. αv\alpha_vαv​ stops simultaneously with uuu.

□\square□

Therefore, the cost of assigning uuu to i′i'i′ is at most

du,i′≤du,i+dv,i+dv,i′≤αu+2αv≤3αu. d_{u, i'} \le d_{u,i} + d_{v, i} + d_{v, i'} \le \alpha_u + 2 \alpha_{v} \le 3 \alpha_u. du,i′​≤du,i​+dv,i​+dv,i′​≤αu​+2αv​≤3αu​.

Question to Ponder. What is the running time of the algorithm?

Finally we show another example where the edge weight between (b,y)(b,y)(b,y) is changed to 1.

Note that compared to the previous example, only facility xxx is selected (marked by dark green), because we can use bbb to contribute only one facility. Now facility yyy is the one that stops αc\alpha_cαc​ and αd\alpha_dαd​ from increasing.

Confidence Interval of Berstein Inequality

Posted on 2018-09-11 Edited on 2019-12-02

(Berstein inequality).
Let X1,...,XnX_1, ..., X_nX1​,...,Xn​ be random variables with range [0,1][0, 1][0,1] and

∑t=1nVar[Xt∣Xt−1,...,X1]=σ2\sum_{t = 1}^n Var[X_t \mid X_{t - 1}, ..., X_1] = \sigma^2 t=1∑n​Var[Xt​∣Xt−1​,...,X1​]=σ2

Let Sn=X1+...+XnS_n = X_1 + ... + X_nSn​=X1​+...+Xn​. Then for all a≥0a \ge 0a≥0

Pr⁡[Sn≥E[Sn]+an]≤exp⁡(−n2a2/2σ2+na/2)\Pr[S_n \ge E[S_n] + an] \le \exp\left(- \frac{n^2 a^2 / 2}{\sigma^2 + n a / 2} \right) Pr[Sn​≥E[Sn​]+an]≤exp(−σ2+na/2n2a2/2​)

Suppose we would like to calculate the confidence interval with probability δ\deltaδ, then we need to solve the following equation:

exp⁡(−n2a2/2σ2+na/2)=δ\exp\left( -\frac{n^2 a^2 / 2}{\sigma^2 + n a / 2} \right) = \delta exp(−σ2+na/2n2a2/2​)=δ

After transformation, we get

n2a2−naln⁡1δ−2σ2ln⁡1δ=0n^2 a^2 - n a \ln \frac{1}{\delta} - 2 \sigma^2 \ln \frac{1}{\delta} = 0 n2a2−nalnδ1​−2σ2lnδ1​=0

Therefore,

a=nln⁡1δ+n2ln⁡21δ+8σ2n2ln⁡1δ2n2=ln⁡1δ+ln⁡21δ+8σ2ln⁡1δ2na = \frac{n \ln \frac{1}{\delta} + \sqrt{n^2 \ln^2 \frac{1}{\delta} + 8 \sigma^2 n^2 \ln \frac{1}{\delta}} }{2n^2 } = \frac{\ln \frac{1}{\delta} + \sqrt{\ln^2 \frac{1}{\delta} + 8 \sigma^2 \ln \frac{1}{\delta}} }{2n } a=2n2nlnδ1​+n2ln2δ1​+8σ2n2lnδ1​​​=2nlnδ1​+ln2δ1​+8σ2lnδ1​​​

But

ln⁡21δ+8σ2ln⁡1δ≤ln⁡21δ+8σ2ln⁡1δ=ln⁡1δ+2σ2ln⁡1δ\sqrt{\ln^2 \frac{1}{\delta} + 8 \sigma^2 \ln \frac{1}{\delta}} \le \sqrt{\ln^2 \frac{1}{\delta}} + \sqrt{8\sigma^2 \ln \frac{1}{\delta}} = \ln \frac{1}{\delta} + 2\sigma \sqrt{2 \ln \frac{1}{\delta}} ln2δ1​+8σ2lnδ1​​≤ln2δ1​​+8σ2lnδ1​​=lnδ1​+2σ2lnδ1​​

It follows that

a=ln⁡1δn+σ2ln⁡1δna = \frac{\ln \frac{1}{\delta} }{n} + \frac{\sigma \sqrt{2\ln \frac{1}{\delta} } }{n} a=nlnδ1​​+nσ2lnδ1​​​

Corollary: If X1,...,XnX_1, ..., X_nX1​,...,Xn​ are i.i.d. random variables and

∑t=1nVar[Xt∣Xt−1,...,X1]=nVar[X1]\sum_{t = 1}^n Var[X_t \mid X_{t - 1}, ..., X_1] = n Var[X_1] t=1∑n​Var[Xt​∣Xt−1​,...,X1​]=nVar[X1​]

Then

a=ln⁡1δn+2Var[X1]ln⁡1δna = \frac{\ln \frac{1}{\delta}}{n} + \sqrt{\frac{2 Var[X_1] \ln \frac{1}{\delta}}{n}} a=nlnδ1​​+n2Var[X1​]lnδ1​​​

Interval Estimate

Posted on 2018-09-02 Edited on 2018-09-16

Let XXX be a Bernoulli random variable with unknown probability

P[X=1]=μ.P[X=0]=1−μ\begin{aligned} P[X = 1] &= \mu. \\ P[X = 0] &= 1 - \mu \end{aligned} P[X=1]P[X=0]​=μ.=1−μ​

where 1n≤μ≤1\frac{1}{n} \le \mu \le 1n1​≤μ≤1 for some integer n>0n > 0n>0. The goal is to estimate μ\muμ (denoted by μ~\tilde \muμ~​) via sampling.

By law of large number, μ~\tilde \muμ~​ converges to μ\muμ when we sample enough numbers of XXX. The convergence behavior is captured by Chernoff inequality and O(1δ2μlog⁡1pfail)O(\frac{1}{\delta^2 \mu}\log{1 \over p_{fail} })O(δ2μ1​logpfail​1​) samples are needed to get an estimation μ~\tilde \muμ~​ such that P[μ~∈(1±δ)μ]≥1−pfailP [ \tilde \mu \in (1 \pm \delta) \mu] \ge 1 - p_{fail}P[μ~​∈(1±δ)μ]≥1−pfail​ (See Exercise 1). Such an μ~\tilde \muμ~​ is called an (δ,pfail)(\delta, p_{fail})(δ,pfail​)-estimation of μ\muμ.

As μ≥1n\mu \ge \frac{1}{n}μ≥n1​, O(nδ2log⁡1pfail)O(\frac{n}{\delta^2}\log{1 \over p_{fail} })O(δ2n​logpfail​1​) samples are enough. The problem is, if μ\muμ is much larger than 1/n1/n1/n, we waste a lot of samples. E.g., when n=1000n = 1000n=1000 and μ=12\mu = \frac{1}{2}μ=21​, 1δ2μlog⁡1pfail\frac{1}{\delta^2 \mu}\log{1 \over p_{fail} }δ2μ1​logpfail​1​ gives us 2δ2log⁡1pfail\frac{2}{\delta^2}\log{1 \over p_{fail} }δ22​logpfail​1​ while nδ2log⁡1pfail\frac{n}{\delta^2}\log{1 \over p_{fail} }δ2n​logpfail​1​ equals to 1000δ2log⁡1pfail\frac{1000}{\delta^2}\log{1 \over p_{fail} }δ21000​logpfail​1​.

Can we obtain an (δ,pfail)(\delta, p_{fail})(δ,pfail​)-estimation μ~\tilde \muμ~​ with just O(1δ2μlog⁡1pfail)O(\frac{1}{\delta^2 \mu}\log{1 \over p_{fail} })O(δ2μ1​logpfail​1​) samples, even though μ\muμ itself is unknown?

Yes we can (with the lost of a factor log⁡log⁡n\log \log nloglogn, which is almost negligible). First we relax the goal a little bit – finding a μ~∈[μ/2,2μ]\tilde \mu \in [\mu/2, 2 \mu]μ~​∈[μ/2,2μ] instead of a μ~∈(1±δ)μ\tilde \mu \in (1 \pm \delta) \muμ~​∈(1±δ)μ. We show how to achieve this with O(1μlog⁡log⁡npfail)O(\frac{1}{\mu}\log{\log n \over p_{fail} })O(μ1​logpfail​logn​) samples.

The high level idea is to divide [1n,1][\frac{1}{n}, 1][n1​,1] into a set of intervals

{[1n,12log⁡n−1],...,[12i,12i−1],...,,[14,12],[12,1]}\{ [\frac{1}{n}, \frac{1}{2^{ \log n -1} }], ..., [\frac{1}{2^{i} }, \frac{1}{2^{i - 1} }], ...,, [\frac{1}{4}, \frac{1}{2}], [\frac{1}{2}, 1]\} {[n1​,2logn−11​],...,[2i1​,2i−11​],...,,[41​,21​],[21​,1]}

Let [12j,12j−1][\frac{1}{2^{j} }, \frac{1}{2^{j - 1} }][2j1​,2j−11​] (j∈N)(j \in N)(j∈N) be the interval that uuu belongs to.

Given an integer iii, such that i≤j−2i \le j - 2i≤j−2 or i≥j+1i \ge j + 1i≥j+1, we can determine whether μ≥12i\mu \ge \frac{1}{2^i}μ≥2i1​ with high probability. We generate O(2ilog⁡log⁡npfail)O(2^i \log \frac{\log n}{p_{fail} })O(2ilogpfail​logn​) samples and test whether their average (i.e., μ~\tilde \muμ~​) is greater than 12i\frac{1}{2^i}2i1​. If μ~>12i\tilde \mu > \frac{1}{2^i}μ~​>2i1​, by Chernoff inequality, μ>12i\mu > \frac{1}{2^i}μ>2i1​ with high probability and the test returns true.

To search for the interval [12j,12j−1][\frac{1}{2^{j} }, \frac{1}{2^{j - 1} }][2j1​,2j−11​] that μ\muμ belongs to, we perform the test for increasing values of i=1,2,...i = 1, 2, ...i=1,2,... until we find the first iii, such that the test for μ≥12i\mu \ge \frac{1}{2^i}μ≥2i1​ returns true. We claim that with high probability, iii takes one of the following values: {j−1,j,j+1}\{j - 1, j, j + 1 \}{j−1,j,j+1}. The reason is that the test returns false (with high probability) when i≤j−2i \le j - 2i≤j−2. The results for i=j−1i = j - 1i=j−1 and jjj are undetermined. Even if the test fails to return true for both i=j−1i = j - 1i=j−1 and jjj, it returns true for i=j+1i = j + 1i=j+1 with high probability.

Finally, after we find an i∈{j−1,j,j+1}i \in \{j - 1, j, j + 1 \}i∈{j−1,j,j+1}, we know that μ≥12⋅2i\mu \ge \frac{1}{2 \cdot 2^i}μ≥2⋅2i1​. Therefore, O(2ilog⁡log⁡npfail)O(2^i \log \frac{\log n}{p_{fail} })O(2ilogpfail​logn​) samples gives an (δ,pfail)(\delta, p_{fail})(δ,pfail​)-estimate of μ\muμ.

Then the total number of samples we generate is at most:

∑k=1j+1O(2klog⁡log⁡npfail)=O(2j+2log⁡log⁡npfail)=O(1μlog⁡log⁡npfail)\sum_{k = 1}^{j+1}O(2^k\log \frac{\log n}{p_{fail} }) = O(2^{j+2}\log \frac{\log n}{p_{fail} }) = O(\frac{1}{\mu}\log \frac{\log n}{p_{fail} }) k=1∑j+1​O(2klogpfail​logn​)=O(2j+2logpfail​logn​)=O(μ1​logpfail​logn​)

The procedure code is shown by Algorithm 1.

Algorithm 1

  1. for i←1i \leftarrow 1i←1 to log⁡n−1\log n - 1logn−1 do
  2. \quad Let θ=6⋅2ilog⁡log⁡npfail\theta = 6 \cdot 2^i \log \frac{\log n}{p_{fail} }θ=6⋅2ilogpfail​logn​.
  3. \quad Let Y=0Y = 0Y=0
  4. \quad for j←1j \leftarrow 1j←1 to θ\thetaθ do
  5. \quad\quad Generate a sample of XXX, denoted by XjX_jXj​.
  6. \quad\quad Y=Y+XjY = Y + X_jY=Y+Xj​.
  7. \quad if Yθ>12i\frac{Y}{\theta} > \frac{1}{2^i}θY​>2i1​ then
  8. \quad \quad return Yθ\frac{Y}{\theta}θY​
  9. return 1n\frac{1}{n}n1​

To analyse Algorithm 1, we use the following Chernoff Bounds.

Chernoff Bound

Let X1,X2,...,XθX_1, X_2, ..., X_\thetaX1​,X2​,...,Xθ​ be i.i.d.i.i.d.i.i.d. Bernoulli random variables with mean μ\muμ and Y=1θ∑k=1θXkY = \frac{1}{\theta} \sum_{k =1}^\theta X_kY=θ1​∑k=1θ​Xk​. Then

  1. P[Y≥(1+δ)μ]≤exp⁡(−δ2δ+2θμ)P[Y \ge (1 + \delta) \mu] \le \exp(- \frac{\delta^2}{\delta + 2} \theta \mu)P[Y≥(1+δ)μ]≤exp(−δ+2δ2​θμ).
  2. P[Y≤(1−δ)μ]≤exp⁡(−δ22θμ)P[Y \le (1 - \delta) \mu] \le \exp(- \frac{\delta^2}{2} \theta \mu)P[Y≤(1−δ)μ]≤exp(−2δ2​θμ)

Corollary

For an integer k≥1k \ge 1k≥1,

  1. P[Y≥2kμ]≤exp⁡(−(2k−1)22k+1θμ)≤exp⁡(−22k−22k+1θμ)=exp⁡(−2k4(1+1/2k)θμ)≤exp⁡(−2k6θμ)P[Y \ge 2^k \mu] \le \exp (- \frac{(2^k -1)^2}{2^k + 1} \theta \mu) \le \exp(- \frac{2^{2k - 2} }{2^k + 1} \theta \mu) = \exp(-\frac{2^k}{4(1+ {1} / {2^k})} \theta \mu) \le \exp(-\frac{2^k}{6} \theta \mu)P[Y≥2kμ]≤exp(−2k+1(2k−1)2​θμ)≤exp(−2k+122k−2​θμ)=exp(−4(1+1/2k)2k​θμ)≤exp(−62k​θμ)
  2. P[Y≤12kμ]≤exp⁡(−(1−12k)22θμ)≤exp⁡(−18θμ)P[Y \le \frac{1}{2^k}\mu] \le \exp(-\frac{(1-\frac{1}{2^k})^2}{2} \theta \mu) \le \exp(-\frac{1}{8}\theta \mu)P[Y≤2k1​μ]≤exp(−2(1−2k1​)2​θμ)≤exp(−81​θμ)

Theorem

Let X1,X2,...,XθX_1, X_2, ..., X_\thetaX1​,X2​,...,Xθ​ be i.i.d.i.i.d.i.i.d. Bernoulli random variables with mean μ∈[12j,12j−1]\mu \in [\frac{1}{2^j}, \frac{1}{2^{j - 1} }]μ∈[2j1​,2j−11​] and Y=1θ∑k=1θXkY = \frac{1}{\theta} \sum_{k =1}^\theta X_kY=θ1​∑k=1θ​Xk​. Suppose θ=6⋅2ilog⁡log⁡npfail\theta = 6 \cdot 2^i \log \frac{\log n}{p_{fail} }θ=6⋅2ilogpfail​logn​ for some iii, then

  1. P[Y≥12i]≤pfaillog⁡nP[Y \ge \frac{1}{2^i}] \le \frac{p_{fail} }{\log n}P[Y≥2i1​]≤lognpfail​​, if i≤j−2i \le j - 2i≤j−2,
  2. P[Y≤12i]≤pfail2i−j−1log⁡nP[Y \le \frac{1}{2^i}] \le \frac{p_{fail} }{2^{i - j - 1} \log n}P[Y≤2i1​]≤2i−j−1lognpfail​​, if i≥j+1i \ge j + 1i≥j+1.

Proof: First consider i≤j−2i \le j - 2i≤j−2. Then 12i≥2j−1−iμ\frac{1}{2^i} \ge 2^{j - 1 - i} \mu2i1​≥2j−1−iμ , 2j−1μ≥12^{j - 1} \mu \ge 12j−1μ≥1 and

P[Y≥12i]≤P[Y≥2j−1−iμ]≤exp⁡(−2j−1−i6θμ)=exp⁡(−2j−1μ⋅2−iθ6)≤exp⁡(−2−iθ6)≤pfaillog⁡n\begin{aligned} P[Y \ge \frac{1}{2^i}] &\le P[Y \ge 2^{j - 1 - i} \mu] \\ &\le \exp(-\frac{2^{j- 1 - i} }{6}\theta \mu) \\ &= \exp(-\frac{2^{j - 1} \mu \cdot 2^{-i}\theta}{6}) \\ &\le\exp(-\frac{2^{-i}\theta}{6}) \\ &\le \frac{p_{fail} }{\log n} \end{aligned} P[Y≥2i1​]​≤P[Y≥2j−1−iμ]≤exp(−62j−1−i​θμ)=exp(−62j−1μ⋅2−iθ​)≤exp(−62−iθ​)≤lognpfail​​​

For i≥j+1i \ge j + 1i≥j+1, we have 12i≤12i−jμ\frac{1}{2^{i} } \le \frac{1}{2^{i - j} } \mu2i1​≤2i−j1​μ , i−j≥1i - j \ge 1i−j≥1 and

P[Y≤12i]≤P[Y≤12i−jμ]≤exp⁡(−μθ8)≤exp⁡(−2−jθ8)≤pfail2i−j−1log⁡n\begin{aligned} P[ Y \le \frac{1}{2^{i} }] &\le P [Y \le \frac{1}{2^{i - j} } \mu] \\ &\le \exp(-\frac{\mu \theta}{8}) \\ &\le \exp(-\frac{2^{-j}\theta }{8}) \\ &\le \frac{p_{fail} }{2^{i - j -1}\log n} \end{aligned} P[Y≤2i1​]​≤P[Y≤2i−j1​μ]≤exp(−8μθ​)≤exp(−82−jθ​)≤2i−j−1lognpfail​​​

It follows that by union bound the test fails for all i=1,2,...,j−2,j+1i = 1, 2, ..., j - 2, j + 1i=1,2,...,j−2,j+1 is at most pfaillog⁡n⋅(j−1)≤pfail\frac{p_{fail} }{\log n} \cdot (j - 1) \le p_{fail}lognpfail​​⋅(j−1)≤pfail​.
